Picasso.passage: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter, sculptor, printmaker, ceramicist, and stage designer who spent most of his adult life in France. He is widely regarded as one of the most influential artists of the 20th century. Picasso is known for co-founding the Cubist movement, inventing constructed sculpture, and for the wide variety of styles that he helped develop and explore. Picasso was born in Malaga, Spain in 1881. His father was a painter and art teacher, and Picasso showed an early talent for drawing. He moved to Barcelona in his teens and studied at the city's School of Fine Arts. In 1900, he moved to Paris, where he became part of the avant-garde art scene. Picasso's early work was influenced by the Post-Impressionist movement, particularly the work of Paul Cézanne. He also drew inspiration from African and Oceanic art, which he saw in the collections of the Musée d'Ethnographie du Trocadéro. In 1907, Picasso painted Les Demoiselles d'Avignon, a groundbreaking work that marked the beginning of the Cubist movement. Over the course of his career, Picasso worked in a wide variety of styles, including Surrealism, Neoclassicism, and Expressionism. He was also a prolific sculptor, creating works in a range of materials, including bronze, plaster, and found objects. In addition to his work as an artist, Picasso was also a writer and playwright. Picasso's personal life was often tumultuous. He had numerous romantic relationships and was married twice. He had several children, including a daughter with his mistress Marie-Thérèse Walter. During World War II, Picasso remained in Paris, where he continued to work and socialize with other artists. He was a member of the French Communist Party and was involved in political activism throughout his life. Picasso died in 1973 at the age of 91. He left behind a vast body of work that continues to influence artists today. His paintings and sculptures can be found in museums and galleries around the world, and his legacy as one of the most important artists of the 20th century is secure.

Van Gogh.passage: Vincent Willem van Gogh (30 March 1853 – 29 July 1890) was a Dutch post-impressionist painter who is among the most famous and influential figures in the history of Western art. In just over a decade, he created about 2,100 artworks, including around 860 oil paintings, most of which date from the last two years of his life. They include landscapes, still lifes, portraits and self-portraits, and are characterised by bold colours and dramatic, impulsive and expressive brushwork that contributed to the foundations of modern art. He was not commercially successful, and his suicide at 37 came after years of mental illness and poverty. Born into an upper-middle-class family, Van Gogh drew as a child and was serious, quiet and thoughtful. As a young man he worked as an art dealer, often travelling, but became depressed after he was transferred to London. He turned to religion and spent time as a Protestant missionary in southern Belgium. He drifted in ill health and solitude before taking up painting in 1881, having moved back home with his parents. His younger brother Theo supported him financially, and the two kept up a long correspondence by letter. His early works, mostly still lifes and depictions of peasant labourers, contain few signs of the vivid colour that distinguished his later work. In 1886, he moved to Paris, where he met members of the avant-garde, including Émile Bernard and Paul Gauguin, who were reacting against the Impressionist sensibility. As his work developed he created a new approach to still lifes and local landscapes. His paintings grew brighter in colour as he developed a style that became fully realised during his stay in Arles in the south of France in 1888. During this period he broadened his subject matter to include series of olive trees, wheat fields and sunflowers. Van Gogh suffered from psychotic episodes and delusions and though he worried about his mental stability, he often neglected his physical health, did not eat properly and drank heavily. His friendship with Gauguin ended after a confrontation with a razor, when in a rage, he severed part of his own left ear. He spent time in psychiatric hospitals, including a period at Saint-Rémy. After he discharged himself and moved to the Auberge Ravoux in Auvers-sur-Oise near Paris, he came under the care of the homeopathic doctor Paul Gachet.

Rembrandt.passage: Rembrandt Harmenszoon van Rijn (1606-1669) was a Dutch painter and etcher. He is generally considered one of the greatest painters and printmakers in European art history and the most important in Dutch history. His contributions to art came in a period of great wealth and cultural achievement that historians call the Dutch Golden Age, when Dutch art (especially Dutch painting), although in many ways antithetical to the Baroque style that dominated Europe, was extremely prolific and innovative. Having achieved youthful success as a portrait painter, Rembrandt's later years were marked by personal tragedy and financial hardships. Yet his etchings and paintings were popular throughout his lifetime, his reputation as an artist remained high, and for twenty years he taught many important Dutch painters. Rembrandt's greatest creative triumphs are exemplified especially in his portraits of his contemporaries, self-portraits and illustrations of scenes from the Bible. His self-portraits form a unique and intimate biography, in which the artist surveyed himself without vanity and with the utmost sincerity. In his paintings and prints he exhibited knowledge of classical iconography, which he molded to fit the requirements of his own experience; thus, the depiction of a biblical scene was informed by Rembrandt's knowledge of the specific text, his assimilation of classical composition, and his observations of Amsterdam's Jewish population. Because of his empathy for the human condition, he has been called "one of the great prophets of civilization." The French sculptor Auguste Rodin said, "Compare me with Rembrandt! What sacrilege! With Rembrandt, the colossus of Art! We should prostrate ourselves before Rembrandt and never compare anyone with him!" Vincent van Gogh wrote, "Rembrandt goes so deep into the mysterious that he says things for which there are no words in any language.

Michelangelo.passage: Michelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni (6 March 1475 – 18 February 1564), commonly known as Michelangelo, was an Italian sculptor, painter, architect, and poet of the High Renaissance born in the Republic of Florence, who exerted an unparalleled influence on the development of Western art. Considered by many the greatest artist of his lifetime, and by some the greatest artist of all time, his artistic versatility was of such a high order that he is often considered a contender for the title of the archetypal Renaissance man, along with his rival and fellow Italian Leonardo da Vinci. A number of Michelangelo's works of painting, sculpture, and architecture rank among the most famous in existence. His output in these fields was prodigious; given the sheer volume of surviving correspondence, sketches, and reminiscences, he is the best-documented artist of the 16th century. He sculpted two of his best-known works, the Pietà and David, before the age of thirty. Despite holding a low opinion of painting, he also created two of the most influential frescoes in the history of Western art: the scenes from Genesis on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in Rome, and The Last Judgment on its altar wall. His design of the Laurentian Library pioneered Mannerist architecture. At the age of 74, he succeeded Antonio da Sangallo the Younger as the architect of St. Peter's Basilica. He transformed the plan so that the western end was finished to his design, as was the dome, with some modification, after his death. Michelangelo was the first Western artist whose biography was published while he was alive. In fact, two biographies were published during his lifetime. One of them, by Giorgio Vasari, proposed that Michelangelo's work transcended that of any artist living or dead, and was "supreme in not one art alone but in all three". The sheer magnitude of Michelangelo's works of art, coupled with his influence on the development of Western art, make him one of the most important figures in the history of art.

Da Vinci.passage: Leonardo da Vinci (1452-1519) was an Italian polymath who is widely considered to be one of the greatest artists of all time. He was also a scientist, mathematician, engineer, inventor, anatomist, geologist, cartographer, botanist, and writer. Da Vinci's artistic talents were evident from a young age, and he was apprenticed to the artist Andrea del Verrocchio in Florence at the age of 14. He quickly surpassed his master in skill and began to develop his own style. Da Vinci's most famous works include the Mona Lisa, The Last Supper, and the Vitruvian Man. The Mona Lisa is a portrait of a woman with a mysterious smile that has captivated viewers for centuries. The Last Supper is a mural painting that depicts the final meal that Jesus shared with his disciples before his crucifixion. The Vitruvian Man is a drawing that shows the proportions of the human body according to the principles of Vitruvius, a Roman architect. In addition to his artistic achievements, Da Vinci was also a prolific inventor and engineer. He designed flying machines, war machines, and machines for lifting heavy weights. He also made important contributions to the fields of anatomy, geology, and cartography. Da Vinci's notebooks, which contain his sketches, drawings, and writings, are a testament to his curiosity and creativity. Da Vinci's life was marked by a restless spirit and a thirst for knowledge. He traveled extensively throughout Italy, studying the works of other artists and scientists. He also worked for various patrons, including the Medici family in Florence and the French king Francis I. Despite his many accomplishments, Da Vinci was never satisfied with his work and was always striving to improve. Da Vinci died in France in 1519 at the age of 67. His legacy lives on in his art, his inventions, and his ideas. He is considered to be a true Renaissance man, embodying the spirit of the age in which he lived.

Renoir.passage: Pierre-Auguste Renoir (1841-1919) was a French artist who was a leading figure in the Impressionist movement. He was born in Limoges, France, and moved to Paris with his family when he was a child. Renoir began his artistic career as a porcelain painter, but soon turned to painting on canvas. He studied at the École des Beaux-Arts and worked in the studio of Charles Gleyre, where he met other artists who would become his lifelong friends, including Claude Monet and Alfred Sisley. Renoir's early works were influenced by the Realist style of Gustave Courbet, but he soon developed his own style, characterized by loose brushwork, vibrant colors, and a focus on the human figure. He was particularly interested in capturing the effects of light and atmosphere, and often painted outdoors, en plein air. Renoir's paintings often depicted scenes of everyday life, such as picnics, dances, and family gatherings, and he was known for his ability to capture the joy and beauty of these moments. In the 1870s, Renoir became a key member of the Impressionist group, which included artists such as Monet, Edgar Degas, and Camille Pissarro. The Impressionists were known for their rejection of traditional academic painting techniques and their focus on capturing the fleeting effects of light and color. Renoir's paintings from this period, such as Luncheon of the Boating Party (1881), are characterized by their loose brushwork, bright colors, and emphasis on the play of light on water and foliage. In the 1880s, Renoir's style began to evolve, as he moved away from the Impressionist style and began to incorporate more classical elements into his work. He was particularly influenced by the works of Raphael and Titian, and began to paint more formal portraits and nudes. Renoir's later works are characterized by their soft, glowing colors and their focus on the beauty of the human form. Despite suffering from rheumatoid arthritis in his later years, Renoir continued to paint until his death in 1919. He left behind a legacy of beautiful, vibrant paintings that continue to inspire and delight art lovers around the world.

Monet.passage: Claude Monet was a French painter who is widely regarded as one of the most important figures in the development of the Impressionist movement. Born in Paris in 1840, Monet spent much of his childhood in the coastal town of Le Havre, where he developed a love of nature and a fascination with the changing effects of light and color. After studying art in Paris, Monet began to experiment with new techniques and styles, eventually developing the loose, brushy style that would become his trademark. He was particularly interested in capturing the fleeting effects of light and atmosphere, and his paintings often feature hazy, dreamlike landscapes and seascapes. Monet's early work was heavily influenced by the Realist movement, but he soon began to move away from traditional techniques and styles. In the 1870s, he began to work outdoors, painting en plein air and using quick, loose brushstrokes to capture the changing effects of light and atmosphere. This approach was revolutionary at the time, and Monet's work quickly gained a reputation for its freshness and vitality. Throughout his career, Monet was fascinated by the natural world, and he spent much of his time painting landscapes, seascapes, and gardens. He was particularly drawn to water, and many of his most famous works feature reflections, ripples, and other watery effects. Monet's work was not always well-received by critics, who often found his loose, impressionistic style to be too radical and unconventional. However, his paintings were hugely popular with the public, and he became one of the most celebrated artists of his time. Today, Monet's work is widely regarded as some of the most important and influential in the history of art. His loose, impressionistic style paved the way for countless other artists, and his fascination with light and color continues to inspire painters and art lovers around the world.

Dali.passage: Salvador Domingo Felipe Jacinto Dalí i Domènech, 1st Marquess of Dalí de Púbol (11 May 1904 – 23 January 1989) was a Spanish surrealist artist renowned for his technical skill, precise draftsmanship and the striking and bizarre images in his work. He was born in Figueres, Catalonia, Spain, and was the son of a wealthy notary. Dalí attended drawing school in Figueres and then went on to study at the Academia de San Fernando in Madrid. He was expelled from the academy in 1926 for refusing to take his final exams, claiming that he was more qualified than his examiners. Dalí's early work was influenced by the Cubist and Futurist movements, but he soon developed his own unique style, which he called "paranoiac-critical." This technique involved creating images that were both realistic and surreal, often featuring distorted figures and objects. Dalí's work was also heavily influenced by his interest in psychoanalysis, which he studied under the guidance of Sigmund Freud. In the 1930s, Dalí became a leading figure in the Surrealist movement, which was characterized by its exploration of the subconscious mind and its use of dreamlike imagery. He collaborated with other Surrealist artists, including Max Ernst and René Magritte, and his work was exhibited in major Surrealist exhibitions in Paris and New York. During World War II, Dalí and his wife, Gala, moved to the United States, where he continued to work and exhibit his art. In the 1950s and 1960s, he became interested in science and mathematics, and his work began to incorporate elements of these fields. He also became interested in religion and mysticism, and his later work often featured religious themes. Dalí died in 1989 at the age of 84. He is considered one of the most important artists of the 20th century, and his work continues to be exhibited and studied around the world. His most famous works include The Persistence of Memory, which features melting clocks, and The Hallucinogenic Toreador, which features a bullfighter and a number of surreal elements.

Klimt.passage: Gustav Klimt (July 14, 1862 – February 6, 1918) was an Austrian symbolist painter and one of the most prominent members of the Vienna Secession movement. Klimt is known for his decorative paintings, murals, and sketches, which often feature erotic and sensual themes. He was also a skilled portraitist, and his portraits of women are particularly renowned. Klimt was born in Baumgarten, near Vienna, to a family of artists. He studied at the Vienna School of Arts and Crafts, where he was influenced by the works of Hans Makart and Franz von Stuck. In 1897, Klimt co-founded the Vienna Secession, a group of artists who sought to break away from the traditional academic style of painting and embrace a more modern, decorative approach. Klimt's early works were heavily influenced by the Art Nouveau movement, and he often incorporated elements of nature and the female form into his paintings. His most famous works from this period include "The Kiss" (1907-1908) and "Judith and the Head of Holofernes" (1901). In the early 1900s, Klimt's style began to evolve, and he began to incorporate more abstract and geometric elements into his paintings. This can be seen in works such as "The Stoclet Frieze" (1905-1911), a series of murals he created for the home of a wealthy Belgian industrialist. Klimt's later works were characterized by a more somber and introspective tone, and he often used darker colors and more abstract forms. He died in 1918, at the age of 55, from pneumonia contracted during the Spanish flu pandemic. Today, Klimt is considered one of the most important artists of the 20th century, and his works continue to be celebrated for their beauty, sensuality, and innovative style. His paintings have been the subject of numerous exhibitions and retrospectives, and his legacy continues to inspire artists around the world.

Pollock.passage: Jackson Pollock (January 28, 1912 – August 11, 1956) was an American painter and a major figure in the abstract expressionist movement. He was widely regarded as one of the most important artists of the 20th century. Pollock's work is known for its unique style of drip painting, which involved pouring and dripping paint onto a canvas laid on the floor. This technique allowed him to create complex, layered compositions that were both spontaneous and controlled. Pollock was born in Cody, Wyoming, and grew up in Arizona and California. He studied art at the Art Students League in New York City, where he was exposed to the work of the European modernists. In the 1930s, he worked for the WPA Federal Art Project, creating murals for public buildings. During this time, he also began to develop his own style of painting, which would eventually become known as abstract expressionism. In the late 1940s, Pollock began to experiment with drip painting, a technique that he had first used in the early 1940s. He would lay a canvas on the floor of his studio and drip, pour, and splatter paint onto it, creating intricate, layered compositions. This technique allowed him to create works that were both spontaneous and controlled, as he could manipulate the paint as it dripped and flowed across the canvas. Pollock's work was met with both praise and criticism. Some critics saw his work as a revolutionary new form of art, while others dismissed it as meaningless and chaotic. However, his work continued to gain popularity, and he became one of the most influential artists of his time. Tragically, Pollock's life was cut short when he died in a car accident in 1956, at the age of 44. Despite his short career, he left behind a legacy of groundbreaking work that continues to inspire artists today.

Pablo Picasso..passage: Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter, sculptor, printmaker, ceramicist and stage designer who spent most of his adult life in France. Regarded as one of the most influential artists of the 20th century, he is known for co-founding the Cubist movement, inventing collage, and for the wide variety of styles that he helped develop and explore. Among his most famous works are the proto-Cubist Les Demoiselles d'Avignon (1907), and Guernica (1937), a portrayal of the bombing of Guernica by the German and Italian airforces during the Spanish Civil War. Picasso demonstrated extraordinary artistic talent in his early years, painting in a naturalistic manner through his childhood and adolescence. During the first decade of the 20th century, his style changed as he experimented with different theories, techniques, and ideas. After 1906, the Fauvist work of the slightly older artist Henri Matisse motivated Picasso to explore more radical styles, beginning a fruitful rivalry between the two artists, who subsequently were often paired by critics as the leaders of modern art.

The African enclaves of Ceuta, Melilla, and Peñón de Vélez de la Gomera make Spain the only European country to have a physical border with an African country (Morocco). Several small islands in the Alboran Sea are also part of Spanish territory. Surrealism..passage: Surrealism is a cultural movement that began in the early 1920s, and is best known for its visual artworks and writings. The aim was to "resolve the previously contradictory conditions of dream and reality into an absolute reality, a super-reality". Artists painted unnerving, illogical scenes, sometimes with photographic precision, creating strange creatures from everyday objects, and developing painting techniques that allowed the unconscious to express itself. Surrealist works feature the element of surprise, unexpected juxtapositions and non sequitur; however, many Surrealist artists and writers regard their work as an expression of the philosophical movement first and foremost, with the works being an artifact. Leader André Breton was explicit in his assertion that Surrealism was, above all, a revolutionary movement. Surrealism developed out of the Dada activities during World War I and the most important center of the movement was Paris. From the 1920s onward, the movement spread around the globe, eventually affecting the visual arts, literature, film, and music of many countries and languages, as well as political thought and practice, philosophy, and social theory.

Gachet's own paintings were heavily influenced by the Impressionists and he exhibited his work alongside theirs at the Salon des Indépendants. After van Gogh's death, Gachet continued to support the Impressionist movement and remained a prominent figure in the art world until his own death in 1909.

The Dutch Golden Age also saw significant advancements in science and technology, with figures such as Antonie van Leeuwenhoek making groundbreaking discoveries in microbiology. Despite its many achievements, the Dutch Golden Age was not without its challenges, including political instability and religious conflict. Nevertheless, it remains a defining period in Dutch history, and its legacy can still be seen in the country's culture and economy today.

Rodin's sculptures often depicted human figures in states of intense physical or emotional turmoil, conveying a sense of raw, unfiltered emotion that was unprecedented in the history of art. Despite his immense talent and influence, Rodin faced significant challenges throughout his career. He struggled to gain acceptance from the artistic establishment, which often dismissed his work as too radical or unconventional. He also faced financial difficulties, and was forced to rely on the support of wealthy patrons and collectors to fund his projects. Despite these obstacles, Rodin remained committed to his artistic vision, and continued to produce groundbreaking work until his death in 1917. Today, his legacy lives on through his many masterpieces, which continue to inspire and captivate audiences around the world.

Gustave Courbet..passage: Gustave Courbet was a French painter who is considered one of the pioneers of the Realist movement in 19th-century art. Born in 1819 in Ornans, France, Courbet rejected the traditional academic style of painting and instead sought to depict the world as he saw it, without idealization or romanticism. He was known for his large-scale paintings of everyday life, landscapes, and portraits, which often featured working-class people and rural scenes. Courbet's most famous work is "The Stone Breakers," a painting that depicts two laborers breaking stones on a country road. The painting caused controversy when it was first exhibited in 1850, as it challenged the traditional notion of what was considered "art." Courbet's rejection of idealization and his focus on the realities of everyday life were seen as a threat to the established order of the art world. Despite the controversy, Courbet continued to paint in his Realist style, and his work became increasingly political. He was a vocal supporter of the Paris Commune, a revolutionary socialist government that briefly ruled Paris in 1871. Courbet was even appointed president of the Commune's art commission, and he oversaw the destruction of the Vendôme Column, a symbol of the French monarchy. Courbet's political activities eventually led to his downfall. After the fall of the Commune, he was arrested and charged with inciting the destruction of the Vendôme Column. He was sentenced to six months in prison and ordered to pay for the column's reconstruction. The financial burden of the fine, combined with his declining health, led Courbet to flee to Switzerland, where he lived in exile until his death in 1877. Despite his controversial legacy, Courbet's influence on the art world cannot be denied. His rejection of traditional academic painting paved the way for the Impressionist and Post-Impressionist movements, and his focus on the realities of everyday life continues to inspire artists today.

Wyoming..passage: Wyoming is a state in the mountain region of the western United States. The state is the 10th largest by area, the least populous, and the second most sparsely populated state in the country. Wyoming is bordered on the north by Montana, on the east by South Dakota and Nebraska, on the south by Colorado, on the southwest by Utah, and on the west by Idaho. The state population was estimated at 578,759 in 2019. The state capital and the most populous city is Cheyenne, which had an estimated population of 64,235 in 2019. The western two-thirds of the state is covered mostly by the mountain ranges and rangelands of the Rocky Mountains, while the eastern third of the state is high elevation prairie called the High Plains. Almost half of the land in Wyoming is owned by the U.S. government, leading Wyoming to rank sixth by area and fifth by proportion of a state's land owned by the federal government. Federal lands include two national parks—Grand Teton and Yellowstone—two national recreation areas, two national monuments, several national forests, historic sites, fish hatcheries, and wildlife refuges.

Arizona..passage: Arizona is a state in the southwestern region of the United States. It is also part of the Western and the Mountain states. Arizona shares the Four Corners region with Utah, Colorado, and New Mexico; its other neighboring states are Nevada and California to the west and the Mexican states of Sonora and Baja California to the south and southwest. Arizona is known for its desert climate, exceptionally hot summers, and mild winters, but the high country in the north features pine forests and mountain ranges with cooler weather than the lower deserts. The state's name appears to originate from an earlier Spanish name, Arizonac, derived from the O'odham name alĭ ṣonak, meaning "small spring", which initially applied only to an area near the silver mining camp of Planchas de Plata, Sonora. To the European settlers, their pronunciation sounded like "Arissona". The area is still known as alĭ ṣonak in the O'odham language. Another possible origin is the Basque phrase haritz ona ("the good oak"), as there were numerous Basque sheepherders in the area.

It was part of the Works Progress Administration (WPA), a New Deal program created by President Franklin D. Roosevelt to stimulate the economy and create jobs. The Federal Art Project employed thousands of artists, including painters, sculptors, photographers, and graphic designers, to create public art and murals for government buildings, schools, and other public spaces. The program also provided art education and training for artists, and helped to establish art centers and galleries across the country. The Federal Art Project was one of the most successful and influential New Deal programs, and its legacy can still be seen in public art and murals throughout the United States.
